known_recommendations.rationale: Increases urine flow rate and reduces concentration of contrast agent in tubules, minimizing direct nephrotoxic effects
known_recommendations.evidence_level: Strong - Multiple RCTs and guidelines (ESR, ACR)
known_recommendations.timing: 500ml saline 1-2 hours before, continue 6-12 hours after

known_recommendations.intervention: Monitor kidney function in at-risk patients
known_recommendations.rationale: Early detection of contrast-induced nephropathy allows for prompt intervention and prevents progression to acute kidney injury
known_recommendations.evidence_level: Strong - Standard of care per nephrology guidelines
known_recommendations.timing: Baseline creatinine within 7 days, follow-up at 48-72 hours post-procedure

known_recommendations.rationale: NSAIDs reduce renal blood flow via prostaglandin inhibition, compounding contrast-induced vasoconstriction
known_recommendations.evidence_level: Strong - Consistent evidence across multiple studies
known_recommendations.timing: 48-72 hours before and after contrast exposure

potential_recommendations.rationale: Antioxidant properties may reduce oxidative stress and free radical damage from contrast agents. Acts as glutathione precursor.
potential_recommendations.evidence_level: Mixed - Some positive RCTs but multiple negative studies and meta-analyses show conflicting results
potential_recommendations.dosing: 600mg orally twice daily for 2 days starting day before procedure
potential_recommendations.limitations: 2018 Cochrane review found no significant benefit; still used in some centers

potential_recommendations.rationale: Magnesium deficiency associated with increased nephrotoxicity; supplementation may maintain cellular energy and reduce calcium influx
potential_recommendations.evidence_level: Limited - Small studies suggest benefit but larger RCTs needed
potential_recommendations.dosing: Magnesium sulfate 3g in 250ml saline over 1 hour before procedure
potential_recommendations.limitations: Mechanism unclear, optimal dosing not established

potential_recommendations.rationale: Alkalinization of tubular fluid may reduce formation of reactive oxygen species and Tamm-Horsfall protein precipitation
potential_recommendations.evidence_level: Moderate - Several positive studies but some negative trials
potential_recommendations.dosing: 154 mEq/L in D5W at 3ml/kg/hr for 1hr before, then 1ml/kg/hr for 6hrs after
potential_recommendations.limitations: Not superior to saline in all studies; logistically complex

debunked_claims.reason_debunked: No scientific evidence for enhanced elimination of contrast agents; may cause electrolyte imbalances and dehydration
debunked_claims.debunked_by: American Society of Nephrology, National Kidney Foundation
debunked_claims.evidence: Systematic reviews show no benefit and potential harm from commercial detox products
debunked_claims.why_harmful: Can lead to dehydration, electrolyte disturbances, and delayed medical care

debunked_claims.reason_debunked: No peer-reviewed evidence for gadolinium elimination; some herbs (aristolochia) are nephrotoxic
debunked_claims.evidence: Case reports of acute kidney injury from herbal products
debunked_claims.why_harmful: Potential drug interactions and direct nephrotoxicity

debunked_claims.reason_debunked: Contrast agents eliminated by glomerular filtration, not affected by dietary interventions
debunked_claims.evidence: Gadolinium elimination follows first-order kinetics independent of diet
debunked_claims.why_harmful: May cause hypoglycemia, nutrient deficiencies, and false sense of protection
